Home
Measuring student learning and needs and driving results

CLIENT EdAI Technologies AB

LOCATION Stockholm

DURATION 1 week (Student Interface) and 2 weeks (Teacher Counterpart)

CONTRIBUTION Individual Contributor

üßë‚Äçüîß The Problem

How to effectively measure student learning and their wellbeing throughout the school session and take actionable steps based on data?

Teachers in Swedish schools have been using assessments like quizzes, exams, exit tickets, daily screenings, lesson evaluations to measure student learning and their wellbeing. Most times it is physical paper-based or through a tool like Google Forms.

Often, it is messy and difficult to keep track of these assessments for each lecture in the long run and teachers spend a lot of time analyzing the results.

ü•Ö Goals


To provide students with a stimulating and fun way of doing quizzes and daily evaluations which can measure their learning and wellbeing effectively.
Goal 1


To provide teachers with the ability to make digital assessments, grade, view results, and analysis as visualizations to make informed decisions for students in need of help.
Goal 2

ü§† Outcomes


We started with single questions and quizzes. It was loved by teachers and they asked for other assessments with enthusiasm.
Outcome 1


The project made EdAider diverse with offerings in assessment and results analysis thereby expanding horizon to distance learning as well.
Outcome 2

üî¨ Prior Research and Information

EdAI team has been working with a team of learning analytics researchers at Stockholm University. We had prior information that teachers expressed interest in a digital assessment system with a variety of assessments.

Once the pilot version with the response system was built, we did a workshop demonstration to observe the usage. The workshop also served as the user research platform about assessments and visualization of results from the teachers.

Assessment definitions
  • Single Questions: These are one-time pushed during a lecture related to the current concept.
  • Quizzes/Exams: Series of questions for weekly or monthly testing. Exams are graded while quizzes may or may not graded.
  • Exit Ticket: A short questionnaire at the end of the lecture to understand the student's learning during that lecture.
  • Daily Screenings: These include questions related to wellbeing and are given once in the morning and once at the end of the day.
  • Lesson Evaluation: Mapping the student's level of understanding in a lesson rather than right or wrong answers.
Workshop Interview Insights

Need for assessments especially exit ticket and daily screenings at least in the starting

A way to create assessments and keep track of them in a central location

Ability to upload existing paper assessments and their results and eventually phase them out

Teachers mentioned that if they have visualizations of the results, it would save a lot of their time

Insights on students who need the most help during the week

Insights on high performing students so, teachers could also use their experience to help other students

Interestingly, that high performing students are sometimes left by themselves as teachers may think they are doing good on their own. The students themselves may feel less motivated since they mastered a concept already. Probably, an adaptive learning system would be beneficial for everyone. But it is an idea for the near future.

üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶ People using our product

Based on the workshop insights, the personas could be defined as below:

üßê Competitor Analysis

Competitors can be hidden and sneaky at times. An example is that water is the major competitor of Cola. Yes, Cola needed to overcome water's thirst-quenching ability to make it successful.

For this project, the major competitor would be the physical paper assessments that are still relevant and used a lot in schools. But they are cumbersome to maintain and the results have to be manually added to a system. There is a chance to replace them easily and this is why we see the rise of many online quiz platforms.

üéûÔ∏è Student Interface

I started out with some sketches and wireframes for the layout of assessments. For the purpose of this case study, I focus on the exit ticket. But the rest of the assessments are also quite similar in layout and design.

  • The general layout for all assessments is quite the same with some differences.
  • The questions can range a few to as much as the teacher desires.

A general feedback was to design a layout where all questions would be visible at once. Though some teachers thought that "one question at a time" layout would be helpful with gamification elements later down the line.

High-fidelity mockups
  • Listing of all assessments in the student interface of lecture
  • Note: Exit ticket, lesson evaluation and daily screenings are automatically pushed by the system, hence they are not visible on this screen during the lecture.
  • Note: While students can check out the questions, they can only answer the assessment once the teacher pushes the assessment from their own system.
  • After all the assessments are finished, they appear on the same screen.
  • Students can see the grade and number of points they earned. Points and grades would form basis of gamification elements later on.
  • Some assessments can also be attempted multiple times.
  • A typical assessment has questions laid out one by one.
  • The questions could be multiple choice and free-text with or without upload option.
  • Some assessments can also be timed but it is optional.
  • Result view of assessment, shows the grade and points at the top.
  • The green box shows any pre-defined comment form the teachers.
  • Post grading feedback is the comment that the teacher gives after grading the question.
Other assessments types

Note that lesson evaluation, morning and end of day screenings are behavioural assessments and are not graded. There is no right or wrong answer. Hence, they do not have the typical results and visualizations as compared to quizzes and exit ticket.

  • Lesson evaluation measures how a student learned and felt about the lecture.
  • The students respond with emojis that signify their feelings.
  • The emojis were adapted from the paper "Supporting learning by considering emotions:Tracking and Visualization. A case study" by Sammara Ruiz et al.
  • Morning Screening gauges how the student is feeling in the morning.
  • Teachers can get insights on any issues if the student did not have good sleep or breakfast.
  • The emojis follow the same adaptation as lesson evaluation.
  • End of day screening is exactly the same as morning screening. The only difference is that it is given at the end of the school day and measures how the student's school day went.

üéûÔ∏è Teacher Interface - Assessment Creation and Grading

A lot of components had already been made by this point so, it was easy to go with hi-fi mockups from the start. While I did do wireframes for the visualizations which need some delibrations.

  • I created an assessments bank that would allow teachers to create various assessments and custom pre-defined responses.
  • Teachers can search and filter assessments based on several parameters.
  • Learning goals is an important metric that would be relevant for analytics later on.
  • From the bank, teachers can create an assessment with three types of questions at the moment.
  • The text area fields are rich text fields which can also have pictures and videos attached if the teacher needs.
  • Teachers can create new questions or import existing questions from another assessment.
  • Any of the assessments can be added to a lecture from the lecture creation module.
  • This was a full project on its own though I present a glimpse of it here.
  • The screen viewed by the teacher when they are grading an assessment.
  • Teachers can assign points and feedback. Points are pre-defined in settings so, grades are assigned automatically based on the points.

üìä Teacher Interface - Results and Visualizations

Here, I have taken the example of a practice quiz which has a higher number of questions. Exit ticket may have 3 or 4 to 10 or more questions. Also, This has an interesting story. The dev team is using highcharts for visualization stuff. But I took some liberty to explore custom visualizations. I started out with a seemingly promising visualization but it just fell flat. I had missed an important consideration.

  • Student view of results page for an assessment.
  • Teachers can grade assessments for each student. They can resume at any time if they left in between.
  • Question wise view of results page for an assessment.
  • Teachers can grade assessments for questions with all answers shown anonymously to them.
After complete grading

At this point another Master's student was working with us on a different project. But I found her idea of quadrant chart useful and directly modified for use in this project.

An important consideration was that a chart visualization in question mode would be feasible and meaningful only when there are a high number of questions for eg. 10 or more. Else they would not be really very useful if for eg. there were only 3 or 4 questions.

‚≠ï Big Mistake

Remember, I told that there was a mistake incoming. The above quadrant chart seemed great at first but it had some edgecase flaws.

  • Since the number of students answering right or wrong is tied together, the bottom right quadrant will never have any data.
  • Also, in case all questions are mandatory then the top left quadrant will never have data because there cannot be lowest number of wrong and right answers at the same time.
I tried a few more visualizations that would resolve the problem.

üéØ Final Outcomes


At this moment, the deve team has developed quizzes, exams, exit ticket and daily screenings. Teachers mentioned that it has increased engagement in class.
Outcome 1


Combined with the response system, the assessments module helped us to gain three Stockholm Stad schools as paid customers
Outcome 2

üïµÔ∏è Reflections

Visualizations is a difficult design area. I am learning to balance creative custom visualizations design with various libraries as to what is possible and what not

Table and charts free up a lot of time for the teachers which they can use for teaching work

Teachers were happy that online library of assessments allows them to replicate and reuse the assessments from the past
